hints_html:
Recall that the general equation for a second degree Taylor polynomial at a is given by:

\[\begin{aligned} T_2(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
Recall that the general equation for a second degree Taylor polynomial at ''a'' is given by:
:<math>
T_2(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2
</math>
question: 1 (j)
sols_html:
To find the second degree Taylor polynomial, we use the equation

\[\begin{aligned} T_2(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2\end{aligned}\]

We know that a =4 and that \(f\)(x)=\(\sqrt{x}\). We can easily compute the derivatives to get

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x)&=\frac{1}{2}x^{-1/2}\\ f''(x)&=-\frac{1}{4x^{3/2}}\end{aligned}\]

Plugging this all in to the Taylor equation, we get:

\[\begin{aligned} T_2(x)&=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2\\ &=f(4)+f'(4)(x-4)+\frac{f''(4)}{2}(x-4)^2\\ &=\sqrt{4}+\frac{1}{2}4^{-1/2}(x-4)+\frac{-\frac{1}{4\times 4^{3/2}}}{2}(x-4)^2\\ &=2+\frac{1}{4}(x-4)-\frac{1}{64}(x-4)^2\\ &=2+\frac{x-4}{4}-\frac{(x-4)^2}{64}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
To find the second degree Taylor polynomial, we use the equation
:<math>
T_2(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2
</math>
We know that ''a'' =4 and that &fnof;(x)=&radic;{{overline|x}}. We can easily compute the derivatives to get
:<math>
\begin{align}
f'(x)&=\frac{1}{2}x^{-1/2}\\
f''(x)&=-\frac{1}{4x^{3/2}}
\end{align}
</math>
Plugging this all in to the Taylor equation, we get:
:<math>\displaystyle
\begin{align}
T_2(x)&=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2\\
&=f(4)+f'(4)(x-4)+\frac{f''(4)}{2}(x-4)^2\\
&=\sqrt{4}+\frac{1}{2}4^{-1/2}(x-4)+\frac{-\frac{1}{4\times 4^{3/2}}}{2}(x-4)^2\\
&=2+\frac{1}{4}(x-4)-\frac{1}{64}(x-4)^2\\
&=2+\frac{x-4}{4}-\frac{(x-4)^2}{64}\\
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Find the second degree Taylor polynomial T2(x) for

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x)=\sqrt{x}\end{aligned}\]

At 4 (or about x =4)
